item.title: The 26-Year-Old Mystery Behind A Cult-Classic SRPG‚Äôs Gradius Sword Has Finally Been Solved
item.content:encoded:
Vandal Hearts II is an obscure strategy RPG sequel produced by Konami at the end of the PS1‚Äôs life. Few played it but many who did will cherish it forever. Now its oldest and weirdest mystery has finally be solved. A reference to Konami‚Äôs classic shoot ‚Äôem up series Gradius mentioned a special sword in the game‚Äôs files that no one could ever get to spawn without hacks. Fans thought up all sorts of wild theories about the ‚Äúintended‚Äù way to unlock the secret, including maybe needing very specific save files from other Konami games like Suikoden. It turns out that they actually needed a super-rare demo disc.

The Gradius Sword in Vandal Hearts II isn‚Äôt just a fun little Easter egg. The weapon contains a powerful spell called ‚ÄúRipple Laser‚Äù that summons an actual 3D model of Gradius‚Äò ship, the Vic Viper, to fly across the battlefield and blow up enemies. It‚Äôs pretty powerful and has a surprisingly ornate animation for something that no one was ever able to discover in the game naturally. The result has been decades of random threads across message boards like GameFAQs and elsewhere as fans tried to figure out what you could actually do in the game to trigger the Gradius Sword to appear.

Three years ago, the tiny YouTube account Dragon Quarter reposted footage of the Ripple Laser skill in action that was originally uploaded in 2010. Then last night, Dragon Quarter returned with a major update. ‚ÄúAfter getting a tip from a follower (who I realize now got their tip from a recent post on GameFAQs) of Twitch streamer Karkalla, who is currently playing through Vandal Hearts II for the first time, I have confirmed the Gradius Sword was originally unlocked by downloading a special save data file from Dengeki PlayStation D22 (SLPM-80471), a demo disc included with Dengeki PlayStation Magazine Issue 116 (dated 1999-09-24),‚Äù they posted on ResetEra on Friday.

According to GameFAQs user Kern, the discovery came after finding a reference to the demo disc on an older Japanese site. ‚ÄúSomeone on a discord who had some old discs found the file on the D22 disc (which you can get from ebay),‚Äù they wrote. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt able to verify it personally myself but he posted images of the file, and he was able to open the save file on an English copy and the Gradius sword was available for purchase.‚Äù Dragon Quarter has since confirmed it as well.

This is the kind of deep gaming lore I thrive on. For years, random players on forums have claimed to have found the weapon early on in Vandal Hearts II just by chance. Is it possible there‚Äôs some one in a million chance for it to just spawn randomly without the demo disc data? Who knows. It seems clear that Konami at least intended for it to be an exclusive bonus for owners of the demo disc, similar to the deluxe edition pre-orders of today that let players begin a game with unique upgrades and gear.

The most absurd theory by far was that you needed to have a final Gregminster save point from the original Suikoden on a memory card to get the Gradius Sword to appear in the shop. When that was debunked a couple of years ago, many players had resigned themselves to the weapon only being available via some hacked save file from ‚ÄúJean‚Äù that was uploaded to GameFAQs over a decade ago. Now players can get it the ‚Äúofficial‚Äù way by downloading a copy of the demo disc save and using a PS3 memory card converter to get the data onto a PS1 memory card.

item.title: Samsung‚Äôs Galaxy Buds 3 Pro Were Pricier at Launch, But Now They‚Äôre Way Cheaper Than AirPods Pro 3

We found this one today ‚Äî 24% off the price of the Samsung Galaxy Buds3 Pro, which brings their price down to just $190. That‚Äôs right in line with Apple‚Äôs AirPods 4 and a big drop from the closer-comparison AirPods Pro3.

The Galaxy Buds3 Pro got a full redesign from Samsung before dropping this past July, with an emphasis on comfort for long listening sessions. The sound is, of course, the amazing quality that Samsung‚Äôs famous for. And these buds are bolstered by Galaxy AI to enhance the noise cancellation, equalization, and more.

Theater of the Mind

Whether you‚Äôre listening to your own playlist or connecting to your tablet or TV via Bluetooth, the surround sound from the Galaxy Buds3 Pro is so good and so immersive it‚Äôs like being in the theater, but the sound is all for you. Dual amplifiers and a 2-way speaker in each bud creates a 360-degree effect, and Galaxy AI powers an adaptive equalizer that optimizes the sound specifically for you.

You can disappear into the listening experience of the Galaxy Buds3 Pro regardless of where you are, because the Adaptive Active Noise Cancellation feature, also powered by Galaxy AI, intelligently adjusts the level of noise cancellation based on your surroundings, and changes is as the conditions around you change. You won‚Äôt want to put them down, and thanks to the comfort-enhancing redesign and long battery life, you won‚Äôt have to.

Futuristic Features

One of the most jawdropping features of the Galaxy Buds3 Pro is the real-time interpreter. When your Buds3 Pro are paired with a compatible Galaxy device, your can carry on a conversation with someone speaking a foreign language and hear the translation on your earbuds in real time. All you need is a Samsung account, from which you can download languages for free. (English and Spanish are pre-installed.)

Will there be incredible tech deals dropping during the two-day Fall Prime Day event? Of course. But consider the several days leading into the event a golden opportunity to find those under-the-radar bargains Amazon likes to drop as they get their inventory set for the big rush. This is most definitely one of them ‚Äî a $60-off deal on Samsung‚Äôs newest and best wireless earbuds. Get the Galaxy Buds3 Pro for just $190 and beat the Prime Day rush.

item.title: Head Magic: The Gathering Designer Apologizes For Misogynistic Card From 27 Years Ago
item.content:encoded:
Magic: The Gathering has finally come clean about one of the bigger stains on its legacy. Veteran head designer Mark Rosewater recently apologized for the misogynistic treatment of a low-level pro player in the ‚Äô90s that he immortalized as a printed card called Ghazb√°n Ogress. ‚ÄúI have had a hand in creating thousands of Magic cards over the years, and Ghazban Ogress is the one I most regret making,‚Äù he wrote in a new blog post.

Ghazb√°n Ogress was a parody of an existing card called Ghazb√°n Ogre, but its real inspiration was a woman named Catherine Nicoloff, an aspiring pro player who also dated several different top players in the ‚Äô90s Magic: The Gathering competitive scene. Part of the 1998 Unglued side-expansion, which was designed entirely by Rosewater, the card‚Äôs description read, ‚ÄúWhen Ghazban Ogress comes into play, the player who has won the most Magic games that day gains control of it.‚Äù It essentially took slut shaming that was happening in private and immortalized it in print.

This darker chapter in the card game‚Äôs history was explored in a recent video on the The Tranquil Domain YouTube channel in which Nicoloff was interviewed about it for the first time. ‚ÄúI just wanted to be one of the guys at the time,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat was the biggest compliment you could get is if you were one of the guys and man, when people say guys don‚Äôt gossip, boy are they lying. So, the attention was mixed, but you were always being watched. I could not go anywhere without being watched. If I went to lunch with a friend, there would be a rumor the next day that I was seen with so-and-so and I was dating him, even if I wasn‚Äôt, even if it was nothing more than a lunch where we were talking about decks or cards or draft strategy or whatever.‚Äù

I laughed at and shared that joke at the time, when I was a teenager, and it certainly can‚Äôt have made women feel welcome in the community. I think one of the worst habits that Magic embedded in me was choosing my social circle based largely on peoples‚Äô perceived skill.

‚Äî Brian Kibler (@bmkibler) May 20, 2021

Nicoloff said Rosewater took her aside during one event to give her a heads-up that the Ghazb√°n Ogress card would be coming out. ‚ÄúMark Rosewater wielded enormous power over the game and continues to do so,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI was just, you know, a a small-time wannabe pro player. So, at that moment, it this is going to sound melodramatic, but it just kind of broke me a little because I had thought Mark was a friend. I thought he was trying to be humorous, but [that] he had the best interests of the players at heart. And now I‚Äôd been handed this tiger by the tail, and I had to either ride it or get eaten by it. That was what Mark gave to me.‚Äù

She ended up signing some other people‚Äôs copies of the card while also trying to collect as many of them as possible to keep it from spreading. Nicoloff reckons she has two binder pages full of Ghazb√°n Ogress now. It wasn‚Äôt until a viral post about the incident four years ago by Magic player Brian Kibler that she wanted to correct the record about what a gross thing it was. ‚ÄúI admit I still felt just a little bit angry and a little bit hurt by the whole thing because this was like an elephant in the room and nobody had ever apologized to me.‚Äù

That changed after the video went live and people started asking Rosewater about it. In a post over on his blog he unequivocally apologized for it. ‚ÄúLet me start by stating unequivocally that it was a mistake to have ever printed the card. It is 100% my doing,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúI designed it and put it into the set. I take full responsibility for the card‚Äôs existence. It‚Äôs important to own up to one‚Äôs mistakes and not try to justify them.‚Äù

Rosewater has since called Nicoloff to apologize 27 years later, an apology which he said she accepted. ‚ÄúThis apology should have come decades earlier though, and for that I am also sorry,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúMagic cards should be something that bring people together and help foster growth and connection,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúIt should never be used to tear people down.‚Äù

item.title: Pok√©mon TCG‚Äôs New Mega Evolution Era Is Looking Way More Generous
item.content:encoded:
Following the non-appearance of a new mainline Pok√©mon game this year, the Pok√©mon TCG was left with a bit of a predicament at the end of its three years of Scarlet & Violet sets. So, rather than drag it on, the trading card game has opted to return to Mega Evolutions, perfectly in time with the giant monsters‚Äô resurgence in the forthcoming Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A. The first new set, out today in the U.S., is aptly and simply called Mega Evolution, and based on opening a few dozen packs, I‚Äôm delighted to report that a newfound generosity seems to have arrived.

Now, while The Pok√©mon Company has chosen to save the really big guns for November‚Äôs next set, Mega Evolution: Phantasmal Flames, and a Charizard card that is likely to cause riots in the streets, that doesn‚Äôt mean there aren‚Äôt some big hitters in this first outing for the new era. Sure to see high demand and higher prices are Special Illustration Rares for fan favorites Mega Venusaur ex, Mega Lucario ex and Mega Latias ex, as well as one very special card: the return of Mega Gardevoir ex. I can‚Äôt hold it in any longer. I pulled it! I pulled the Gardevoir!

OK, I‚Äôm not going to let this color my assessment of the set, but I will say I when I opened it last night I ran upstairs and woke up my son to show him in quite the display of excellent parenting. Oh, and the centering on the reverse is awful, so there‚Äôs no hope of a nice PSA rating. Right, moving on.

Another New Beginning

While the ex cards continue to appear, although only in Mega Evolved form here, Mega Evolution does represent something of a resetting of recent trends in the TCG. For instance, the completely out-of-control reverse holos with either Pok√© Balls or Master Balls on them are all gone, and in fact the reverse holo has no pattern at all. There are no holo Energy cards, no Ace Spec-likes‚Äîjust a very basic set of a very normal size (188 cards). As such, in this sense, it feels like an appropriate wiping clean of the slate for a new era. In another sense, other than the Mega Evolved Pok√©mon, it‚Äôs an incredibly ordinary set, too. The art on a large number of the Basic cards is weirdly generic, images that look so plain that you‚Äôd swear you‚Äôve seen them before.

This makes for an odd set in some ways. With no new Pok√©mon arriving, and the indistinct art, most of the cards feel like they could come from any era in any of the last ten years. However, when you pull something more special, they feel very special, and I‚Äôm delighted to report that in our smallish sample, that happened a lot more often than I was expecting.

So Pok√©mon TCG sets in recent years have been built of your regular cards with the small window of art, Double Rares that are either the older basic Vs or the more recent basic ex cards, Ultra Rares which tend to be more elaborate V/ex arts or full-art Trainer cards, then the desirable Illustration Rares (IR) which are full-art cards depicting Pok√©mon in their environment, followed by Special Illustration Rares (SIR) which also full-art, but mostly far more elaborately detailed. Then you get your gold cards which used to be the most prized, but more recently lost all their allure‚Äîthis time out there are just two of them, with a lot more detail etched into the gold foil, and the hilarious new classification of Mega Hyper Rare. Mega Evolution sticks to this formula but with a boost, giving those Illustration Rares a big upgrade: the artworks in this set are astonishing.

Each time I pulled an IR I was convinced it had to be an SIR, so gorgeous and elaborate was the art. Cards like the Clawitzer, Bulbasaur, and Ivysaur IRs would previously have easily been given an SIR rating. And yes, that means the 10 SIR cards have stepped up too, all of them (but for the Mega Absol ex, I would argue) looking like they could have been the ultimate chase card in any set on their own. Mega Latias ex is just extraordinary, while the Mega Lucario ex seems to be deliberately evoking the classic Mewtwo vs Charizard cards of the Sword & Shield era, as the Lucario soars over a city, wheeling back to punch an attacking Venusaur. And talking of it, the Mega Venusaur ex card completes a triptych set with Bulbasaur and Ivysaur in gobsmacking artwork by very new Pok√©mon artist mashu. And then, yes, there‚Äôs that Mega Gardevoir ex, with a degree of intricacy not seen since Akira Egawa‚Äôs Giratina VSTAR in Crown Zenith. (Egawa designed the Mega Latias in this set.) What‚Äôs more extraordinary is that the Gardevoir card was designed by an artist brand new to the TCG, Raita Kazama, who has previously designed incredible packaging and sleeves for the franchise, but never a card.

Pull Rates

Pull rates over Scarlet & Violet felt like they were crawling by the end, settling on a pretty desultory 1 in 5 chance of a pack having something you‚Äôd care about, even including a basic ex. Mega Evolution (and again, I stress my sample size is non-scientific) blew this out of the water for me. Of the first 40 packs, I pulled 12 cards Ultra Rare or higher! If you include the basic ex cards (which look great, by the way) that goes up to 21 pulls from 40 packs. 1 in 2?! And better than 1 in 4 for real pulls. That‚Äôs so much more appealing, and a far better use of someone‚Äôs allowance.

What‚Äôs The Meta?

As for how all this will affect the game itself, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôll be pretty big stuff. The Mega cards are as powerful as you‚Äôd hope, and are going to absolutely flip the meta. Mega Gardevoir ex, for instance, has a one-Energy ability called Overflowing Wishes that lets you add an Energy card to every benched Psychic Pok√©mon you have at once, and a second called Mega Symphonia that‚Äôll deliver 50 damage for every Psychic Energy attached. It‚Äôs a Stage 2, so you‚Äôre not going to be playing it out your deck, but at the same time that gives you a lot of time to build up its Energy stock while you evolve it. Meanwhile, Mega Abomasnow ex could possibly deliver the highest damage I‚Äôve ever heard of. Hammer-lanche has you discard the top six cards from your deck, doing 100 damage for every Energy card that‚Äôs there. Load your deck with Energy and you could hit for 600! Albeit at a hefty cost for your reserves of cards, of course.

Mega Camerupt ex can deliver a ludicrous 240 damage for one Energy if the opponent is Burned, while my favorite, Mega Mawile, can take a Huge Bite of 260 damage if an opponent is unharmed (and only 30 if it isn‚Äôt!), but also Gobble Down for 80 per prize card you‚Äôve taken. What a finisher that would be, your opponent finally playing their stacked Mega Gardevoir with five prize cards gone, and you clobber it in one turn for 380.

There are also nice twists like Wally‚Äôs Companion, a Trainer card featuring good ol‚Äô Wally that will heal all damage from an ex Pok√©mon at the cost of returning Energy attached to it back to your hand. Yup, it‚Äôs not discarded!

This is to be a very brief set, given the arrival of Phantasmal Flames as soon as November 14. It‚Äôs an even shorter time if you live outside the U.S., where Mega Evolution has been delayed by a full two weeks due to manufacturing issues‚Äîbarely a month long. But it‚Äôs a lovely way to begin the new era, unless I was just ridiculously lucky!

item.title: This 4.7-Star Ryzen 7 Mini PC Plays Cyberpunk 2077 at a Record Low Price, Better Gaming Value Than Mac Mini
item.content:encoded:
City apartments don‚Äôt offer a ton of living space. So if you find yourself in either a one bedroom or studio, you‚Äôre going to have to make some tough decisions surrounding how every square inch gets used. This is especially true when it comes to your desk setup. It may not be worth it for you to dedicate a tone of surface area to a huge PC tower. Go with a mini instead. The Geekom Mini PC AX8 Max is currently on sale for 29% off. It‚Äôs normally priced at $749 but has come down to just $529. That saves you a staggering $220.

See at Amazon

AAA Gaming on a Mini PC

This compact case measuring in at only 5.4 by 5.1 by 1.7 inches contains a full-on PC powered by an AMD Ryzen 7 CPU and AMD Radeon 780M graphics card. As far as mobile integrated GPUs go, this one is pretty darn good. You might actually be able to play some of the more demanding games out there like Cyberpunk 2077 so long as you keep it in minimum graphics settings. And then lots of smaller indie titles should play pretty smoothly. You can actually even connect the AX8 Max to an AMD discrete graphics card over one of the USB-C ports to improve your graphics further. The mini PC has also got a fair amount of memory with its 32GB of RAM plus a full 1TB of storage on its PCle SSD.

Mini PCs are pretty perfect for your ‚Äúeveryday‚Äù computer tasks. By that I mean the day-to-day stuff like browsing the web, sending out emails, queuing up a YouTube video, or doing anything you need in Microsoft Office apps like PowerPoint, Excel, or Word.

With the two USB-C ports and the two HDMI ports, you can actually connect to up to four displays at once without the help of a dedicated docking station. Over USB-C, you can achieve an 8K resolution at 30Hz while the HDMI 2.0 ports can get you 4K resolution  at 60Hz. And since the PC is so small, you can just mount the whole thing to the back of one of your monitors, taking up no surface area on your desk at all.

The Geekom AX8 Max can be set to three different modes, based on your needs in the moments. First up is the default mode. Not much to say there. Next we have quiet mode which can reduce power consumption and noise. Great for some light office work or while studying and needing to focus. Then we have performance mode which is optimized for AAA gaming.

item.title: Pok√©mon Took Over A Major Wrestling Event And It Absolutely Ruled
item.content:encoded:
Remember last month when Game Freak revealed that Hawlucha would get a mega form in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A with an animated sports drama starring the luchador bird and a Machamp? Well, Nintendo partnered with real luchadors to bring this fight to life. Last night, Pok√©mon took over a Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre event in Mexico City that had several luchadors dressed in Pok√©mon-themed costumes, including two who referenced the rivalry between Hawlucha and Machamp.

The Pok√©mon and Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre collaboration was a two-hour event full of drama, mayhem, and references to different Pok√©mon in both costuming and in the set dressing. The ring in which the bouts took place included Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A branding (or Leyendas Pok√©mon Z-A, as it‚Äôs called in Spanish). Attendees were given paper hats of Hawlucha and Machamp to wear in the stands, and Pikachu and Eevee mascots were hanging out the whole time. If you want to watch the whole thing, it‚Äôs on Pok√©mon Latam‚Äôs YouTube channel, but do keep in mind this was a Spanish event. I don‚Äôt speak a word of the language, and the vibes are still pretty great.

Those who attended the event were gifted a Pok√©mon Home medal featuring art of Hawlucha and Machamp squaring up. As of right now, there are no plans to distribute this anywhere else outside the event. For those of us who couldn‚Äôt make it out to Mexico City, the VOD is still a really fun intersection of Pok√©mon and a specific culture. Lucha libre wrestling and its aesthetics have been featured in Pok√©mon before, both with Hawlucha itself and the Pikachu Libre cosplay variant in Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire, but this event takes that energy to a new level, and it‚Äôs fun to see people in the crowd playing into that crossover with their own costumes and chants.
